And they had this strange concept of keeping your job title and level a secret, similar to the secret of your salary. Thus you don't know who your peers are.Expect the "acid test" your first year there

easy doing day.

hardest part is answering to multiple mangers.
the job is easy when left alone, thats what i like most.no thank you
Jll will challenge you. You will work hard but you will be rewarded. Overall a great experience and a good place to work. I would work for them again.Okay Place to Work

At JLL, I was Digital Marketing Associate in the Business department in order to help them to develop business through the website and social media. I learned how to gather coworkers around one project thanks to training sessions and initiatives. To develop the website I was in contact with the UK team and I created some processes to move faster on that project.
In JLL, the workplace culture was and is amazing, people are stressed of course but are able to make jokes at the same time. As it is an American company, the management is strong but is giving a lot of freedom to the employees. The hardest part of the job was the adaptability because I worked with different departments, profiles and skills. The most enjoyable part of the job was the management of Instagram for the company because I had to create the Digital Marketing plan and launch the social media. Plus, thanks to Instagram, I could discover a lot of places in Paris and participate to a lot of activities.Real estate and social media

Here at jll, there is a lot of promises when your first hired and prior. You soon realize that you have to wait years to advance, spite your knowledge and talents. I work for the att account. Call outs are unforgiving. Called out all times of night. Performing two and three man jobs by yourself. The business motto changes as often as every year. A poor place to work with other people constantly negotiating a contract every year, so you can keep working. The changes Iâ€™ve seen in almost five years where dramatic. These changes jll made got us kicked right out the door.A dead end road.
enjoyed my time at JLL, great people, fun working, challenging, this was contract work, wish it would have lasted longer or could have gone into a full time positiongreat place to work
Great Benefits. All depends on which location you work at. Some locations have great people to work with and a wonderful atmosphere. While others are hostile.Ok Place to Work

JLL overall is a great company offering wonderful benefits and a lot of diversity. It depends on your assigned account as to your success. Many people move between different accounts and tend to move up.Good Company but account assignments vary

JLL's culture is based on client approval ratings. Though there are many company based policies and procedures, many clients also have preferences that need to be met in addition to company procedures. Day-to-day work can be fast-paced and require new, different tasks based on property operations, audits, and ownership changes.Fast-paced, detail oriented, client approval

The company puts full trust in you to do your job efficiently and with integrity. You enter your own time for work orders and therefore you get paid for the total time that you worked each day. There are time constraints on how long you are given to complete each task, but it can be modified by your supervisor if more time is need due to complications. That said, the time constraints are not cumbersome in any way if you know what you are doing, and there is plenty of help if you need it.No time clock needed!

Every day was like walking into a bad television show. The pay was great, the time off was excellent. My co-workers were all depressed. All felt taken advantage of and underappreciated. The management (or lack thereof) was yellow-bellied and cowardice. Never standing up when they saw something was wrong. Especially when it came to safety. And no raise in sight so ask for all the money you want for the next 3-5 years.Terrible management, depressed co-workers

Our firm was bought out by JLL so the exposure to the corporate culture was gradual. The benefits were immediately available which was nice. Standardizing the workplace per JLL standards was a bit of an ordeal but I felt like they made it as smooth as it could possibly be. JLL has a lot of great resources like 24/7 tech support that you just don't get a most companies (like when I needed help setting up a VPN to work on Christmas morning from home...). Weekly webinars to help career development and held which is highly recommend. Networking and volunteer events are common and encouraged. The healthcare package and benefits like Real Appeal have benefited me inside and outside the workplace.Strictly business with care for the employees

poor management, no consideration for employee welfare. typical response when issues are raised is "put your head done and get back to work". very bottom line oriented with no though of customer satisfactionincredibly poor management

I like working here. Very balance and good benefits too. A lot of room to grow. This is a client based therefore the only downside is the contract from the client does not get renewed, The team needs to find other positions internally.Great Company

Upper management was always cutting corners to save money. Many jobs were eliminated to hire overseas employees happy to make minimum wages. No job security, call center was always being downsizedCorporate culture- no job security

You will be forced to work and not paid for any extra time worked. if you say you will not work you will be threatened to loose your job. JLL Contract job.

I went through 4 Facility Managers within 9 months.

*Let that be an indicator to the work culture, environment, and management.

Non-existent JLL training to do your job properly.

Non-existent help from upper management. Ghosting you when you email your manager. I repeatedly asked for help and was talked down to by a manager who was an off- site manager who was supposed to be giving assistance to us, as we we're still trying to learn our jobs. Very hostile person. This person should be fired. It's a true sign as to why they can't keep employees in this particular site.

Asking you to do more jobs without compensation, or proper training. Essentially throwing work on you that you don't know how to do.

Absolutely no support or direction. I guess that's why they've gone through so many managers for the last 15 years.

Managers messing with your pay!

GM managers were demanding and demeaning towards JLL employees, as well as their own employees. GM employees making inappropriate comments, making everyone feel real uncomfortable.

Toxic and hostile work environment! Almost criminal!

JLL is a good place to get a job. The manager and the colleagues are nice and compatible. the working environment is excellent. however, the salary is a little bit low.Relaxed but competitive working environment

Aggressive growth firm. No micro-managment. Flexible work styles and work life balance encouraged. Better than average benefits.

Onboarding haphazard. Not much communication from dept. head.Good compnay with some growth pains
Good salary, lots of opportunity for advancement.Firm is evolving to focus on the human experience which includes their employees, clients and customers.Professional environment.

Verry solid company. Has a good culture, process and Goals. Have a good benefit package that helps on your work performance(motivation and peace of mind) Working teams are verry knowledgable and team work oriented. Growth opportunity is available.Challenging, Busy, Change

I enjoyed the company in my earlier years of employment, however, as the company grew, silos of accountability were created within the facility operations teams (PDS, Analytics, Management, Strategic Sourcing, Operations, Financial, etc.) that has become a detriment to efficiency. Great Place to work. Straight shift. Off on holidays and get paid for holiday. Company has high rate of moving into a better position and will not hold you back.Productive and fun place to work. I enjoy it.

Each day starts the same way the budget ! How can we keep our commitments to the client while Our organization (JLL) grossly underestimated the cost of operations at this site. The culture is relaxed and collaborative at JLL. Management was supportive and gave employees autonomy to handle projects. Benefits were great and health insurance was 75% paid for by the company.Collaborative environment with forward thinking management
It was a Wonderful place to work. A bit boring at times but do not have any complaints. Great benefits, wonderful PTO. It was not easy leaving. would work there againwonderful place

Wonderful company to work for. The training is awesome and the staff is great. Only downside is if a client doesn't renew a contract they might not have a position to move over too.Great Company

Staggered month-ends for properties allow for workload to be spaced out reasonably throughout a month. Luckily, I found a small number of people willing to show me the ropes and, since then, the work has been stable and manageable. good place to work but there are a lot of loop wholes that need to be addressed and there is poor management and payroll is way off because they checks bounces and they take money out your check for no reason and they dont give paystubsgood place to work

I was quickly moved up the ladder at JLL based on my skill and performance, and loved the teams with which I worked. I was allowed to work from home when needed, giving me a great work/life balance. I was also given new responsibilities frequently, and trained on how to complete them successfully. My coworkers were wonderful, all hard-working and interested in doing a good job. The hardest part of the job was that in some ways, you need to be a self-starter and very self-motivated in order to excel. Luckily, I am, and I did. I really enjoyed the multiple opportunities I was able to seize in order to move up within the company. Great benefits, great attention to employees' needs, overall a great company. Unfortunately for my own personal reasons, I had to move on.Great company, loved working there!

JLL doesn't have a competitive salary package but they get you with their benefits. You start out with 18 PTOs which increases to 23 upon your three year anniversary but it's not worth the salary. Once you are in at a salary, be prepared for only 1-3% raises each year if anything at all. I have been at this company for over seven years and they didn't give me a salary raise this year. Fun to work with the people there but no one is looking out for you. If you want to pave your own path and don't care about salary, this is the spot to start your career.Company keeps you with their benefits
Company has amazing benefits with vacation time and insurance. Night shift is beginning to take a tole on my family and sleep pattern.Productive and informative place to work.
Best company i ever work for. Good for college students. Management is the best. I would recommend people to work for this company. Great benefits.Enviroment

This company operates in a virtual reality world, or at least the part of the company I worked for, where everyone works remotely. My manager was in Florida, while I was in Arizona. We never met face to face we only spoke on the phone or communicated via email. She had no knowledge or experience in how to do my job and claimed to have hired me for my expertise; yet refused to listen when I would advise her on how things should be done and was quick to criticize and sit in judgment when something she told me to do failed. It is a very cold impersonal company. I was like an island out in the middle of the ocean. There is no over site or supervision. I was not in a management role yet I was expected to assume such responsibilities without compensation or recognition.Bad Management in a Virtual World

I have worked for JLL on 2 different accounts and they are night and day. The JLL Benefits and perks are second to none. PTO is great, holidays and healthcare are great. The account you work for make all the difference on how much this matters. My first account was about getting things done and keeping great records. My most recent account is more about penny pinching and dealing with frustrated and sometimes irate clients because you cant get work done due to budgetary slowdowns and cost deferments. I also have to deal with onerous paperwork for the sake of paperwork and redundant systems that only make getting work done confusing.Great comapany to work for some accounts are better than others

Fantastic overall company culture, leader in commercial real estate. Great place to learn the ropes and be given a chance...especially for new graduates. Financially successful, stable company. However JLL is a large company and initiatives and good intentions from corporate don't always trickle down to the numerous offices and remote employees on client sites. There are too many incompetent managers and supervisors that are promoted and kept on in spite of their inadequacies. However that can be expected with a large company. Working for JLL has been a pleasure. I have had three different managers in the year and a half that I have been with the company and I am pleased to say that they were all extremely helpful and constructive. My work hours are flexible, being that all my clients are in the west coast. I start work at 11 am and end at 8pm. I can also work from home as much or little as I would like. As far as compensation, I believe that through the work I have demonstrated I deserve to make more. All management agrees with me but the team does not have a ton of money being that we are fairly small and new within JLL. I have a masters degree in Industrial Engineering and management concentration and do environmental efficiency work for my current position. I have learned and developed many skills and can genuinely say that JLL has taught me more than my four years at school when it comes to management, running a team, being a leader, and developing your skills. The work culture is friendly and inviting. My coworkers are extremely helpful and the atmosphere is very team oriented. Although I love working for this company and greatly enjoy my job I do not see a set path for my career advancement. I would like to have more responsibilities and challenges and would like to move up in my career.work review

No day is ever typical; most of the work I do is based on client needs. While there are contractual deliverables - reporting, defined performance metrics - flexibility is key. If the client's business climate is changing, we need to be able to adapt to that and change course on a moments notice. I've learned to be flexible and open minded; I've learned a lot from the clients that I have worked with both from a business/industry perspective, but also how to work with a variety of personalities from C-Suite to engineers in the field. Everyone needs to understand the communications that are coming out so I try to make sure to appeal to all audiences. The best part of my job are my co-workers and forming relationships. It doesn't matter how long ago you worked with someone, you may need their assistance/knowledge some day so it's satisfying when I get the call "I heard you may know....".

I have enjoyed the variety that my job gives me and the hardest part of my job is satisfying my clients, but it is also the most rewarding.Variety...Variety...Variety

Overall is a good place to work and to learned. They have a great team in Raleigh.Great Company
Overall experience has been very educational and . I am very satisfied with all my time with the company.Very satified working for this company

Overall corporate benefits are very atractive, including encouragement to work from home for all corporate staff. This is very important for mother of young kids like me. However, the people who are put in management level are not qualified for people manager. I have received great opportunities and experience with JLL. I have had the opportunity of working with several vendors, contractors, and other JLL departments on projects for clients.learning workplace
My team was very professional and easy to work with. Management was fair and very professional. Great benefits!Great company to work for!

Usually a good place to work, however there appeared to be a good ole boy network at higher levels. I am a man and very few woman in higher levels. Also, accounts poorly audited at high levels, too much room for curruption, especially if your account is making money.Good company, poor management chain

JLL has great benefits. But be prepared to work like a dog. And don't even think about having a life outside of work cause you will always be at work. The pay is pretty good, but for the all the duties they ask of you, it is truly not worth it! Also, the management is horrible. Some of the managers are very cold and impersonal and could care less about your career growth. It was so bad for me, I left there to take a lower paying job!Great benefits. Horrible work/life balance. Horrible management.

I very much enjoyed working for JLL. Being that JLL is such a large company, it's a bit less personal as far as career guidance and mentoring are concerned. Especially the NYC office was always hectic, but I enjoyed being exposed to and able to develop personal relationships with all of the top executives across all different business lines. The job security and benefits were most definitely a plus. A typical day at work was always interesting during my time as a project manager because we were overseeing so many different projects simultaneously, so really we had to devote our time to whatever was the most important task at hand; a lot of 'putting out fires', but it was fun. While working for the President of the NY region, my days were more predictable including working on presentations, setting up meetings, travel and whatever operations tasks were needed. The most enjoyable aspect of the job for me was learning new methods of management, the creation marketing materials, and the contacts/friends made. The hardest part of the job for me was not the actual work, but I would prefer to work in a slightly less corporate environment, if it were up to me. But overall, JLL is a wonderful company and I am very grateful for my time and experience spent as a JLL Employee.Jones Lang LaSalle

I used to work 1 year for JLL.
I had always feelings somebody keeps me on eye......
I was fired with no comments by a journeyman.... I do have 2 Master Licenses.
U should be an American born to work there, otherwise u might end up fired like myself because I'm not.
I'm glad I'm out.Unhealthy enviroment

Working at Jones Lang Lasalle for nearly 17 years was representative of the continuing opportunities within the company. Learning and gaining experience in all client environments was key. The hardest part of the job was keeping clients satisfied with the product delivery, speed to market and cost savings/KPIs. The most enjoyable part of working at Jones Lang Lasalle was the strong support system and exposure to continuing opportunities. All of the Jones Lang Lasalle employees were very focused, hard workers, and fun to work with with. Leadership was aggressive with hitting financial goals. This was at times difficult but necessary considering the competitive nature of the corporate real estate business.Collaborative environment with emphasis on client satisfaction

Excellent benefits early morning start
8am. began work over at 5pm.

I also had to deal with over 75 vendors outside of Jones Lang lasalle. This position is a position that requires diversity. On a typical day, I may encounter individuals from diverse backgrounds, diverse cultures, and diverse beliefs. Serviced and maintained chillers for AT&T.
Under staffed and underfunded, maintainence on critical systems had been deferred for years and management blamed the crew and let the chiller techs go.
The engineer from AT&T who coordinates the work with JLL is a total nutcase and has absolutely no people skills. Sits in a dark office all day tinkering with his programs on his computer. They are trying to get run down, in many cases, obsolete equipment to preform like it is new. Some of the equipment is so bad that it is beyond repair. The salt air has destroyed a lot of the equipment but AT&T still insists that it can be made to operate as if it is new.
The worst thing was when management, to save their jobs, blamed the chiller tech crew for all the problems instead of themselves for understaffing and not hiring seasoned veteran help.Great company with really bad local management

Jones is a great firm to work for. However, in this economy they have had to do several lay-offs, and unfortunally, I was one of the unlucky ones. They are great about giving you proper notice and delivering an acceptable severance. If I could have stayed here...I would have.Great Firm
JLL was (overall) a good experience. I worked on the AT&T account. This was a new account and we had massive turn over. In a few years, things will settle down.JLL was a (overall) a good experience

Great company to work for that gives you opportunities to advance and grow within the company.

About the Company:
Jones Lang LaSalle is a financial and professional services firm specializing in real estate services and investment management. Our more than 40,000 people in 1,000 locations in 70 countries serve the local, regional and global real estate needs of those clients, growing our company in the process. In response to changing client expectations and market conditions, we assemble teams of experts who deliver integrated services built on market insight and foresight, sound research and relevant market knowledge. We attract, develop and reward the best, and most diverse, people in our industry, challenging them to develop enduring client relationships built on quality service, collaboration and trustWonderful Place to work

Kaiser has been good to me. Would recommend this company. Started working here right out of High School. Great Medical benefits for employees and family.Great company to work for.

Huge non profit organization. Strong culture. Fine benefits and salary.
Lack of teambuilding and really interesting things there. Have to learn something at first.Fine

Kaiser works with loyalty to their employees, which is why it is hard to get a job in the first place with them. They first post the position within the department allowing for anyone to advance within. If no one wants it then they allow anyone from other departments to apply, and then still if no one wants it they allow people from the outside to apply. Even then, it's competitive! Depending on your position and shift will determine what your hours are. For my position, there was a clear training period and a list of what you were supposed to learn. The workplace culture was very supportive and there was always clear communication between everyone - from lower staff to management to other department heads. The hardest part of the job is keeping calm during an emergency code, but that will take practice. I learned about being much more observant, clear communication, and the importance of getting information to people as fast as possible. The best part about working here I think is the culture, because everyone - and I mean everyone - is really supportive. Yes there are bad days and good days like any company but at least here, the average day was a good one working with good people.Hard to get in, but worth it

Exceptional place to work. Aside from the many benefits Kaiser offers; they also cultivate a workforce that is motivated and cultured. Despite the quick paced work required to be accomplished, it's well worth it.Exceptional Place to Work

Great place to work. love coworkers there, high employee retainment. great place grow with good benefits. Kaiser is top heavy and sometimes hard to reach managementIt is a nice place to work. Great benefits too
All team members were happy working there. Positive work environment. HR and union are willing to help if needed. Great benefits and pension. I recommend it.Great structured environment

Overall Kaiser is a great organization. They have EXCELLENT pay and benefits. HOWEVER, certain managers have killed morale and created horrible work environments. UNAC union has the back of their nurses.Overall Kaiser is great.....

Good working with fellow co-workers. They come to work everyday and work hard with each other. Also help each other when one co-worker is having issues we all try to help each other like family.working with others

Each day we would create rates with our underwriters for our brokers and clients. The position was fast-past, especially when we were enrolling a new client with our benefits. I learned alot regarding how benefits work (especially HMO plans), I learned how to network and build relationships with our brokers, clients and other team members at the company. My manager was a great mentor who helped me become a better leader and how the underwriting worked regarding creating rates for our healthcare plans. The most enjoyable part of my position was working as a team to assist our clients/members have the best experience with the company from the enrollment process to getting their claims reviewed and paid.Enjoyable company to work for

If you are a hard worker and don't get involved in politics of the place you can make it a good gig for some time. Working within occupied facilities can be challenging and an adjustment to the production work preformed in the field. It was great at the start because you are pretty much guaranteed a 40 hour week and generally the work is not hard to preform. But as things get slower there's always a core crew and if you have no close friends/family in management you can plan on receiving your 2 checks no matter how good of a worker you have been.Working as a carpenter for Kaiser is an easy gig but is hard to last without family and friends!

Always wanted to work for the company. Had high expectations and they exceeded them for years.

Kaiser has many aspects that make it an amazing company to work for. The people are amazing, hard working, union keeps things fair and management works fairly.Kaiser is awesome company to work for

I loved working at Kaiser and helping our patients have the best experience at every visit. It was hard work and emotionally difficult at times, as any job in healthcare can be. I learned a lot in every department that I worked for cross trained in, from the different medical terms used in each department to the required paperwork. My last manager was willing and able to jump into our job when staffing required and understood what we went through on a daily basis. She would back us up when we needed it.
The hardest part of working here was losing patients due to health issues or old age. You get to know them and it is really sad when they pass. The best part is the ability to help patients through the system that you know but which is sometimes really confusing to them.Great place to work with great benefits

Easily the best job I've had as an LPN. People work as a team, genuinely care about your needs, and you always have something to do. The company does cater a bit too much to their patients so they can sometimes be demanding without merit,Great place to work

Kaiser Permanente is one of the best places to work, as an advice nurse I get satisfaction knowing that I have taken good care of the patients even on the phone because you hear it in their voices. You do have what you need to do your job efficiently and independently. You are recognized for what you do and your contributions are valued. Work environment is safe and friendly while the benefits are great. Continuous education via on the job training is not stressful while the job expectations are clear, understandable and easily achievable. The culture at Kaiser is to thrive in good health. Gym and healthy snacks are open and supported for the staff with security provided for safety at all times. Retirement benefits are provided. The management team are friendly and cordial.my opinion

The most enjoyable part of my job is the staff and the rewards from seeing us all grow as a family. Working together, learning new skills together and being part of a team is what keeps us strong. My typical day at Kaiser included checking all work orders, checking energy management systems, and making sure the buildings where safe for employees and patients. Kaiser was one of the best jobs I ever had, the management was fantastic. They encouraged everyone to have fun, and always provided me the tools I needed to successfully complete my job. There was no hard aspects of this job, only reason why I left was because Kaiser closed up on the east coast, and moved back to California. The most enjoyable part of the job was to go and interact with great people.Very fun place to work, no stress, Excellent Management
This is a great place to work with great people to work with and great benefits. I really enjoyed my time working there and would recommend this place of employment.Great
Most jobs here require you to work rotating weekends and sometimes hours and shifts vary. Alot of jobs are non union which means there is absolutely no job security.Fast paced work environment

They'll give you whatever you ask for during the recruiting process, but the happy atmosphere and the work-life balance are lies. They expect you to take your laptop home and work all day Saturday and all day Sunday. The younger crowd constantly complains about management, and even though the health benefits are great it's hard not to find issues with daily quality of life in the office, at least on the corporate level.Work Life Balance is a Lie

Enjoyed the job there unfortunately I had to move out of state. Great place to work and employees make it great. I would have a busy day and they appreciated your work and benefits and compensation makes it worth whileMedical assistant

They hired me from India in 2000, relocated to USA. Even though salary was less I accepted offer. They did spend a lot of money in relocation, hotel accommodation, car driving lessons, rental assistance, greencard sponsership, 401k, various benefits package. I did not understand all those benefits package as I was new to USA, it was my second job. I worked hard, put more hours as needed, expected one or 2 promotions, quicker greencard. They should have given correct updates regarding Greencard Status. They should not have outsourced to TCS and then slowed our greencard processing. They should have counseled me from doing Full-time MBA (since my greencard did not come after 7 yrs I tried doing Full-Time MBA to get greencard in EB2 category) to do part-time / Executive MBA and when my I140 was approved they should have rehired me back immediately, continued processing my greencard. Once they brought us to USA from India on the promise of greencard, they should have led, mentored me till I get greencard and permanently settled in USA. That was not difficult. Still they can do that.Excellent Place to work in USA for long term and even life time

had agreat team of employees,managers,physicians and all ancillary departments ere great.acute crae patiens with all kinds of diagnosis,and leared agreat deal in kaiser.they well train their staff in quality patient care along with good financial outcome.al staff wa strained in good customer crae nad they gave continued education on different subjects.from team leading to nursing administratin,they contined thier teaching and was a great place to work with excellent benifits.kaiser was the best hospital i ever worked.i enjoyed my work,eventhough at times it was stressful

always something new to learn. We were trained in every part of the Kaiser Pharmacy Hospital. I worked Oncology because I had a work schedule Monday-Friday. Almost impossible in hospital work.
Great company to work for.Kaiser was an great company to work for great benifits and pay
kaiser offers great benefits and flexible hours and always there was overtime which was optional. Management was very strict and focused more on company goals than employeesgood benefits

The organization seeks to provide member with preventive care so that members can be informed and can take there help into there own hands.Productive and Innovative

Great company, amazing staff and the benefits can not be matched anywhere. Lots of opportunity for advancement and Kaiser really invests in their employees. Like any job you get out what you put into it.Great Place to Work

Start brown-nosing on your first day and you'll be fine. Don't think outside the box - just be a robot like they want you to. Kaiser is a huge company and your work experience at Kaiser really depends on what location you end up at.

I enjoyed my time at Kaiser and I definitely learned a lot during my 13 years there.

The hardest part about Kaiser was the day to day politics and the most enjoyable part was being able to make a difference in peoples lives on a daily basis.My job was stressful but I enjoyed it. Management could be a bit underhanded but my co-workers were like family and I enjoyed helping people.

Work/ life balance needs improvent high expectations on salaried managementioned positions

Relaxed environment and good team building and compensation is excelent but very competitive at manager levellong work hours. Good compensation management mixed good with some not so much

Kaiser Permanente is a nice place to work, depending on what department one is working for. A typical day is full of busy work, and tons of learning opportunities, depending on the position. However, overall Kaiser Permanente is a nice place to work.Nice place to work

Many employees have worked there for more than ten years. It is a fast paced environment. Very strict on attendance policies. Good benefits for full time employees.

Management like to hire their friends for positions rather than hire more experienced candidates.Productive

Avoid management. Very corrupt environment where half of the staff is there because they had some connection to someone and not based on being an outstanding candidate. Few do the work for most of the others. Great benefits and great pay, but unbelievably frustrating dealing with the politics.Great pay, but very stressful
good long term company but it can be very political. This company is very black and white. Sometimes the company is not as loyal to you as you are to them.The company as a whole

very good work / life balance, great benefits, great pay and nice culture at work, people seems won't ever leave working for the company. some locations have Gyn and yoga rooms for exercise.It is a very safe place to work

I don't have much to say I like kaiser and never want to leave thee benefits are good but some of there managers are mean especially the kaiser in fontanaGood

Most employees are friendly and have a positive attitude.
On the job training and trained in multiple positions. If you work hard, you will be given lots of hours.Great place to work
Kaiser has very good benefits for employees. It is fun to work here. The system they used is very helpful to provide the best patient care for patients.Benefits
Great place to work! Great people, excellent benefits. If you want to help people, then work for Kaiser. It is very hard to gain employment, so it helps if you know someone.Kaiser Westside

Very high stress fast paced. You even in the technology field are dealing with peoples lives. KP rewards it's employees. On one hand I am glad I left, on another I really miss it. Family changes and personal issues that could not be handled while dealing with this type of position came up. I felt it best to move on. Kaiser hires really good people. Great benefits and pay. Will pay for education advancement but really need to advocate for advancement. Able to get involved in unit based team meeting to make work environment better/given input.Great pay and benefits

Kaiser was a great company to work for, I was spending a lot of time at work working early clinics, regular clinics and night clinics. Wonderful and fair company to work for. Would work for them for the duration of my career if possible. Good benefits, good work-life balance. Other employees fantasticWonderful Company
Great company enjoy the job, the benefits are great, potential growth. Opportunity to relocate. Regular bonuses, union reps, great incentives. Job securitymedical setting
Kaiser is a pretty nice company to work for. At times it can become stressful if you don't know how to balance life. The pay and benefits are great...Re
Great place to work but could use some improvements when balancing home life and work. I really like the pay and the benefits that we are given. It is a great place for insurance.good
Great place to work. relaxed environment with excellent compensation package. KP provides excellent communication skills with leadership that cares and pays close attention to detail.Great place
Kaiser is more focused on growing number of patients. They have not yet caught up with increased staffing to handle increased patient loads. Provides good benefits.Needs more staffing

I have been working at Kaiser for over 6 years from UCT to RN. Best place to work for anybody, very good pay , and benefits. Good educational support for employees. Growgh is encourage by mangers and the company.Best place to work.

Great place to work. Job security , a lot os benefits. Compensation very high.

Huge spacious office, fully equipped with a variety of teas, coffees and sugar to keep you up. kaiser is great in paying their employees. management changes constantly. it has pros and cons . need more continuing education and an excellent critical care educator. need more bonuses.great company to work for.

a very enjoyable place to work for. typical day is busy however management is very supportive and makes the job very great to work for. hoping for better benefitsGood

The staff and providers are great to work with... willing to teach and help with understanding of a diagnosis and/or procedure. Providers are appreciative of your help and expertise.

It is a good company to work with , good people, technoklogy, worktime balance , pay is okay, benifits okay, lot of opportunity, lot of advanced technology.employe friendly company

I love Kaiser Permanente and I will retire here! I have not had too many negative experiences here that had to do with the job directly itself and I have been through a variety of departments. Every patient is not so nice but staff and management are so friendly and supportive! I love Kaiser and how they are diverse, lots of races, cultures, genders, orientations and ethnicities to work with! Kaiser is a very professional environment, so only the best and top work is expected but there are so many incentives. Kaiser pays high wages for each level and division of staff they have. I am an LVN making $37/hr and I an max out at $42. Some of the RNs are making $80/hr+, housekeepers $20+ They pay for school, all your licenses, throw lots of parties, bonuses and raises. Idea place to work, excellent benefits and great pay. I enjoyed working with the doctors and learned alot about the departments. Worse part of the job was my schedule 1030 to 630 and the commute.I relocated.Fun place to work lots of activities for the employees

More positions converting to work from home positions. Most positions have flexible hours.

The best place to work for diversity, culture, patient care, and benefits. I learned everything I needed from Kaiser. It's a very caring organization from the top down. Even with the restructuring going due to the Kaiser Permanente acquisition, management old and new seem to have the employees best interests in mind. This company has great benefits. Enjoyed the team atmosphere and the independence with the protocols in place. Can be fast paced but had support when this occurred.Good overall comp;any

I can only speak about my experience at the specific location I was working. The job itself was not stressful, it was the environment and some of the co workers.I also found it to be" clique-ish". It is terrible when a person is new and still learning the "Kaiser Way" that there is constantly negative criticism. Instead of correcting the issue, the management would rather let you burn and sink. Kaiser does pay well and the benefits are awesome, but it is not worth putting your license and integrity at risk. Like I said, it is not all of Kaiser I'm speaking of, just one specific unit and location. I did meet some awesome people there, but I met more people that are not. Everyone's experience is different, but for me it was not very pleasant. Don't just look at the pay, look at the culture when deciding on working here. Good Luck!!Think twice about working here

12 hour shifts, 3 days a week. Great opportunities for overtime and for extra shifts. Getting time off for holidays is very controlled by the Union. Otherwise, really good benefits.Consistent work, great benefits

Love working at kaiser, they have good pay and great benefits. I love the staff, my manager is soo supportive, they provided staff whatever they need in order to be a good nurse and they have good community serviceLove working at kaiser, they have good pay and great benefits

I loved it, though it may not for everyone, due to being so fast paced. There are high expectations and always an opportunity to advance and shift to a new setting within the company. Pay is above average and benefits are unbeatable for the union positions.

Direct management was generally fair, supportive and competent in my experience. Overtime was available as an FTE but never mandatory, PTO was very generous and easy to take time off, even with union system in place.

Management is so so. You have to be on their good side.

great company I would work for them again if I got a chance the company what taking over my job with keyos machines.

So Kaiser can be a great place to work, but you have to understand it will take years and years to get off of night shift, and if you have experience when you are hired in NEGOTIATE YOUR PAY BEFORE YOU SIGN ANYTHING! They have a pay scale based on experience but they will short you if you don't speak up- I was shorted about 6 years of experience and didn't realize it until I saw my union contract. This is something you won't find out until you have already signed away your ability to negotiate, so be aware of their pay scale and don't sign until they match your pay with your experience. I was shorted approximately $10/hour due to this, and was one of the reasons I quit the job. Also make sure they have you on the right pay scale for the department you work in- level 2 would be inpatient, level 3 and 4 for critical care and ER- and these pay differentials add up to a lot of money. I personally believe that Kaiser has gotten so big that it isn't able to adapt at a reasonable pace to changes in patient load and staffing, which is why you can expect a phone call almost every day to come in for short-staffing. There are also way too many mid-level managers whose main job is to do chart audits and get people written up. I never had this problem, but I saw a lot of people who were called into the office frequently over charting semantics. You are lucky to get your breaks. They also were not the most accommodating to me as a breastfeeding mother- I received a lot of negative comments when I would have to take a few extra minutes on my break to walk across the hospital to the pumpingKaiser can be good and bad

I have been with Kaiser for 17 years and I find that it is a beneficial place to work it is a starter place for young adults. Just starting off I would recommend Kaiser to any and everyone.I really like the diversity with this company

Large organization. Leader in health insurance and health care. Breadth of career opportunities is very large. Mature organization where many people spend their careers.Strong Corporate Employer

Healthcare benefits make it worth working at Kaiser. There are staffing shortages and an overuse of agency staff. Management are not often present during regular staff working hours, and are absent at the weekends often leaving problems to be worked out by day shift staff.Great place to work with great healthcare benefits.

Kaiser is a great company to work for. Once you're in, you're IN! There's so much room for advancement plus they offer tuition reimbursement. Working 20+ hours will get you benefits. The pay is great and so many shifts to choose from for various departments.Kaiser permanente is great
Responds to requests in a timely fashion. Understands dynamics of the culture of safety within the work place. Provide exceptional compensation benefits.Great company to work for.
It's a solid stable job, but very high in volume. Also not crazy about being in a union. Especially since the union dues are 2.5% of your pay every paycheck.Great paying job, very high in volume

Like the title says, its a great place to start off with. They have amazing benefits, PTO, training, and excellent pay. Weekends are an extra $1.50 an hour and Government holiday pay is DOUBLE.
Very strict environment with strict supervisors but they work one on one with you to help achieve goals. Everything you do is completely looked over or supervised, mistakes happen but they expect perfection. The decisions you make are based on intuition, questions and concerns are not black & white; there are a lot of grey areas.
Many associates stay for years and complain about the job, other employees are short lived and advance to a different company.Great place to get your foot in the door

Kaiser is very supportive of advancing your practice and has educational benefits and programs. Work - life balance is talked about a lot but doesn't seem to be supported in reality.good money, support for education

Kaiser is a challenging environment if you are in IT. Many vendors and the environment is very bureaucratic and political. Coworkers are great but management is often weak and obstructionist. Additionally, they will work you all hours of the day and night. The prevalence of Big Four partners vying for business makes the environment complex to work in.

Change management process is overly cumbersome compared to many shops I have worked in - many where it has been very thorough. (In fact, the process did not work well due to the intensity of the process).Great co-workers, lousy management
Many opportunities to grow within the company, great benefits , excellent training, always up to date on compliance. Work hours are accommodated if neededFast paced and enjoyable

Good benefits and PTO
people are friendly
heavily union environment

Although Kaiser does compensate well for benefits and pay, they are not at all what they preach. I love working with Kaiser because it is very well know hospital and very much to work with managers, employee, and over all the benefits are well implemented.Productivity, very at ease to work.

Amazing job that paid better than a living wage and gave great benefits. I moved out of the area and have no been able to find a company that even comes close to comparing.Best Job I Ever Had

Kaiser gave me a place to grow individually and professionally. I completed my education while working full time. Kaiser offers tuition reimbursement.Excellent workplace to develop a career.

Great place to work.

Planning on working here until I'm ready to retire.
Great Benefits.
overall the best job I've ever had.great place to work

mostly because of the people. Helping them in they're time of need.
Answering question that the visit's, may have about there billing.
Are assisting those who need services render regarding there Ins. Coverage.

Being a supporting factor, at time when people would come into the ER, alone and frighten, for one reason are another.

excellent benefits

care about employees
fast paced

your day to day work is dependent on your local boss and the regionexcellent benefits, good challenges

The first thing in the morning is to get the report of the patients so I know what is going on. Things can change during the day as patients come with different needs.great place to work with great team work

loved union and management they are willing to help you and work with your schedule, working for them was great and the benefits are also amazing. definitely would recommend this to a friendkaiser
working here was good experience and the benefits are amazing. the people are very helpful and training was easy. I loved my job but my assignment ended to soon.interesting

working with family members can be difficult

I enjoy working for Kaiser! I'll never leave! The compensation is excellent and my co-workers are the best. My manager is outstanding. Since Kaiser uses LVN's minimally, the only issue is when you work as an LVN there aren't many opportunities and hours. Thus, leaving an on-call position to a benefited one is challenging. It may take over a year or two to convert or bid on a job. As an on-call employee you have the lowest of seniority when it comes to bidding rights no matter how long you've worked there. However, getting in to Kaiser as an on-call employee doesn't mean you won't get hours. You may get 40 hours/week which will then make it easy for you to convert to a benefitted position. Kaiser is a beautiful place to work. There are many opportunities for advancement and movement.Excellent Corporation

one has so many benefits, it is always busy there is also a lot of technicians working there, therefore the workload is not that bad. Will definitely apply once again when I'm done with my masters program.Kaiser is perfect

Kaiser Permanente is an enjoyable place to work with many advancement opportunities. In addition they offer excellent benefit and pay.Everyone is always happy and upbeat.Many chances for advancement

8 hour is a typical work day, you learn something new because Kaiser always has the MD up to date on the latest treatments, management is changing and asking the employees what they can do better, the most valuable part of the job is the members.work day

I enjoy working with them is a very good company. If I had the choice to go back I will there has not been another job like Kaiser Permanente. Nice patients I use to work at the infusinfusion center.It was a very nice place to work

I worked in a management level position where I had to work closely with lots of managers, directors and executives. There was constant turnover among the managers and those at the top do not know how to lead. There is little to no accountability for managers/directors who do not get their work done or provide you information that you need. It makes it almost impossible to do your work.

It is also a very political place which can make it very hard to move up -- I've seen people passed over for promotions because the hiring director did not like the employee's SUPERVISOR (nothing to do with the employee or their work).

I think if you have a union job, things are MUCH better. Hard to get fired, excellent benefits and lots of job security.Excellent benefits, horrible management

it was all business. management didn't have the greatest relationship with employees due to inexperience in our field. It made it hard for management to understand and implement ideas. This forced them to coexist with employees and find new and better ways to handle everyday tasks.amazing coworkers

Secure and well paying company with free healthcare. Pension benefits, if invested after 5 years. Routine job, but can make a difference if desired (ambition, go-getter mentality). Good Company. Good company. Good company to work for. Good Benefits, nice people to work with. Reliable management staff. I would recommend this company to work for. ThanksGood Company

Small office with less than 9 people provided for a laid back work environment with regards to office politics. High pace workload as we needed to get the orders out to our vendors for rapid delivery to patients. Able to build relationships with medical personnel to include Doctors and nurses. As with any office job, it did get sort of repetitive after a while, but loyalty to my department and the patients I was helping, led me to stay focused. My manager was fantastic, taking me under her wing and teaching me the ins and outs of the department.High pace office environment in the medical office field

I enjoy working for Kaiser Permanente. I have been working with this company for over eleven years. My typical work week consists of rooming the patients, taking history and assessing the patients complaints. I work week days. I appreciate the variety of skills I have learned and the continuing education the company provides.
I love the diverse population of patients I get to take care of. I am always learning, there is never a dull moment. Most people assume working in a clinic does not have as much excitement as the hospital or other facilities, I believe it does. The gratifying part of my job is the patients. Most of the time, I learn new disease processes or presentations of by the patient. I am also humbled by how strong humans are when they are in control of their health.
The hardest part of my job is not being able to spend more time with the patient.
I am saddened to leave Kaiser Permanente.

truly enjoyed my time at Kaiser.awesome place to work

KP is a good place to work in terms of compensation and benefits considering it's a nonprofit. I was warned, in so many words, about the culture that existed but I thought I could rise above it. I was gravely mistaken. Working in an environment that fostered gross bullying and mistrust nearly cost me my life. The best thing Kaiser did for me was terminate me.Toxic work environment perpetuated by senior leadership

Working there was very relaxing and slow- pace. I enjoy my job 100% of the time. I've never had any issues in the position. I was comfortable with all benefits the company had to offer.I enjoyed working with productive employees

Great company to work for from mid-90's to current if you are a part of TPMG owned by physician's medical group. There is job security and benefits are the best. Moved into a corporate position in Regional quality during a time of new executive directors who were not competent in their leadership of the newly reorganized business unit between patient safety, quality regulatory services. I didn't receive training, started head into the middle of projects and was not given opportunity to work with another peer consultant. With 20 years of clinical experience my boss didn't find me a good fit. I requested for training in performance improvement and was denied. I was nominated by my peers, but my boss just didn't find me as a good fit. She evaluated me well in behaviors but in skill she felt I was not the right fit and would be better off in clinical since it is my strongest area. She terminated me and gave me 25 minutes to clear my desk after 18 months with quality but 19 years with Kaiser Permanente. She also made it clear that I was not hireable with Kaiser which is up to the manager that is terminating the employee. Thank goodness for my BSN and MPH, otherwise being loyal to a company will leave you in the dust. For me it was raining that day and my boss couldn't wait for me to get out and left my things outside the building although she offered for me to come back and pick up from security office. Heartbreaking the way my job ended with KP, but my career anticipates new beginnings.

be careful with management and comb through actual areas you would like to work for.Kaiser Foundation Health Plan
Good place to work, good pay and benefits, but RNs sat on the phone answering questions all day. Local upper management was very cold. Immediate supervisor great.great pay

hard to get in, but once you're in, it's great. advancement is hard though, but no one wants to leave because the benefits are too good. some management teams will work hard to help you, while others aren't too great at leading.Great benefits

There was very high turnover in the past 3-4 years, which created a work overload for those who were left. On one hand this created opportunities for people to break into the organization, and on the other hand, training people took months before they could really stand of their own two feet. More senior people had double or triple the workload. In my inexperienced days this provided a great chance to get to know the corporate world. Learn the etiquette and business side and improve my speaking and presentation skills. But as someone with a different calling, I outgrew this career. The most enjoyable job is definitely traveling onsite to companies in the Bay Area and talking to members. That and the people I had worked with were kind and giving. The hardest part was those latter years when we were severely understaffed (amongst many other things) that led to a stressful workplace. However our immediate managers were understanding and tried to help as much as they could. Unfortunately, it wasn't enough; Upper management wasn't as connected with us and didn't understand how to help.Overall
You had to work very hard, but the pay was better then any where else. I was thankful once the Patient ratio was implemented. I was just in the process of starting my new business.Very Good

I grew with my last company as far as I could as they were much smaller than KP. I took a position to get me started with KP but with the hundreds of applications coming in, I find it difficult to advance and compete. I feels like my past experience is overlooked by my current position. The most enjoyable part of my job is that I do not ever get stressed, I am well supported by my manager and peers.Kp

Working at an advice triage RN for Kaiser is akin to working in a prison camp. En masse, you are assigned specific breaks and cannot use the bathroom or get a drink or snack outside of those times. There are cameras EVERYWHERE so there is literally nowhere to make a personal call; you are even forbidden from leaving the building during your lunch break. Dress code is extremely bizarre and random, no scarves or jewelry--which is odd b/c there is no patient contact. There is extreme tension between management and staff. Daily, edicts are handed down with new rules which are enforced in a draconian manner. Every call you receive is recorded and you are encouraged as a new advice triage nurse to ask your charge for assistance or advice. When you do, and execute that exact instruction, you can be written up if it veers at all from the "manual." Further, do not think that asking the advice MD on call for his/her advice will be heeded. Even their call on difficult decisions (whether a pt should go to ER or primary dr) is irrelevant if it doesn't follow the 'manual." And no amount of documentation will cover you. BEWARE. I have never experienced such a back-stabbing culture in my many years in healthcare. The pay and benefits are excellent but you must muscle through the tricks and games played by your management.Pay and benes are excellent, work culture treacherous

Great Company, Great Benefits. A good company that allows it's employees to move to other positions that interest them and has a great program to take classes on line for free.Great Company, Great Benefits

Does not care about its employees, especially nursing staff. I was employed at their Southeastern division. There is not a REAL Nurse's union like they have on the west coast. It is a food worker's union. At first when you are hired, they tell you how much you are needed, valued and happy to have you working there, then they downsized the nursing staff wurhout any notice. It's even worse if you are part of the Supplemental staff. The Administrators pressure you to work as much as the fulltime staff. If you work in the Call Center, you have to work the same amount of holidays as a full time employee, but you do not earn paid time off or sick days. My typical work day start at 6 and end at 2:30. I've learned how to process claims and to problem solve. Also I've learned how to work with outside vendors in recouping overpayments on claims. The hardest part of the job is that what I do as a Claims Recovery Specialist is it's always busy, but I like the challenge of my job, it keeps you on your toes at all time, because day and day out you must know how to mulit-task and problem solve. its the best place to work .low co pays. friendly staff. great management. free premiums for health insurance. 401 k . etc etc etcbest place to work

A typical work day involved working closely with physicians and other providers to deliver healthcare to Kaiser members. Throughout my 25 years I've become comfortable with multiple computer systems. I have also learned quite a bit about health care to include issues of different body systems, the importance of immunizations, and I've learned how to communicate with and care for patients.

I have always found co-workers that have been willing and able to work as a team. As with any work environment, I have found those who were willing to go above and beyond as well as those who were there to do the minimum and collect their pay. Although there have been some exceptions, the majority of my work environment was stable and supportive.

The most challenging part of my job was the pressure of keeping the workflow going as required by the company for patient satisfaction. Patients often have a different degree of needs that sometimes require additional attention. I commend Kaiser for addressing patient satisfaction but as with most companies staffing could not always accommodate demands. I must also add that as a medical assistant you will learn a lot however there is no opportunity to advance in that role unless you personally take the time to further your education.

The most enjoyable part of my job was meeting and caring for patients.Secure work environment with excellent benefits
Horrible Management in Pharmacy but compensation is good. Hard to keep a balance between work and home life because you're so understaffed and often asked to work overtime.Poor Management

Greeting patients calling by there names and id bracelets taking vitals rooming patients giving information to doctors, making sure patients are feeling comfortable. My usual shift at work starts with the multitasking of heavy phone calls coming in, family visitors asking questions, patients calling for their nurse, nurses asking for appointments to be scheduled for their discharging patients and more. Swing shift at a hospital is the busiest of times and doesn't let up for hours, if you're lucky. The night continues with admissions and discharges of patients and moving patients around from either higher or lower acuity or isolation needs. Working very closely with management to ensure policy's are being followed for patient care.
Maintaining a constructive working environment is essential as I work with all levels of specifically trained educated personnel.

Not having enough time in a shift to get everything done would be some attributes to job difficulties. Although there are some days that too much time is available and finding ways to stay busy would be the task.

Kaiser is absolutely the BEST place to work. The pay is excellent. The benefits are amazing. Annual raises and bonuses. Employee discounts and perks. Advancement is encouraged. I was able to help individuals who were having difficulties communicating with the Covered California Marketplace to gain coverage. There was no financial incentive for my actions, I spent extra effort to make sure those "who had slipped through the cracks",
got coverage. I did it because it was the right thing to do; even as an experience health insurance agent, I have learned that the efficacy of your enrollment depends on the skill of your advocate, and with the explosive growth of agents in this marketplace, these skills are not uniformly placed.
Your enrollment is in the hands of the last person you talked to....Making a Difference

What enjoyable place to work,excellent benefits,talent galore,flexible hours,plus comparable salaries and not to mention the extraordinary bonuses and raises. The national organization is outstanding. They truly care about their members and employees. The local employees are some of the best I've ever worked with. Senior leaders (with rare exception) treat people poorly and then try to force a "be happy or be punished" agenda. Sad to see a once thriving, happy place to work turn into a place of mediocrity and a culture of fear and ignorance.Great national org, poor Hawaii leadership
Nice place to work. Just needs to increase the pay of their workers and stop expecting too much if you not going to pay well.Ok place.

It was a pleasure assisting members in a assertive manner and ending the closing of call with my members smiling and satisfied with the quality service that I had rendered.Dedicated and fast paced exciting enviroment

Kaiser pays top dollar to nurses, as we are given raises twice a year for the first five years, then, annually by union, and every other year by by Kaiser. The raises are about 4% which is almost $2.00/hr each raise. I started as a new grad 8 years ago at 32.00/hour and am now at 58.00/hour, not adding night, or weekend differential. Our benefits are excellent. Our union dues are not high, as many people think, but they really do not do much for us.
The management, however, is not that great. They encourage a culture of computer nursing, by not caring about staffing needs, or workload ratios. And even when we win service awards, we are not given recognition. I know nurses complain about this often, but we have too many traveler nurses who can not wait to leave at the end of their contract, stating that they NEVER had to work under such stressful conditions.
The best part about Kaiser is the people we work with. It feels like we all have to pull together as a family does to get through the stressful conditions.great pay for stressful environment
It's a job in social services that pays the bills,thats about it. There's not much to say but some case management jobs are hard depending on the caseload and requirement of the job.stable job

Start with bad hours since 24 hour call center, but can gain good hours quickly.
Nice Managers and great people to work with.
Awful parking.Great Company to Work For

Great company with advancement opportunities. However, there is an EXTREME lack of communication between management and employees with unique circumstances.Great company with advancement opportunities.

If you like to keep busy and enjoy working in the medical field, Kaiser is a great place to work. I learned a lot in my first few years working for Kaiser, but find it difficult to move up in the ranks.Kaiser Sacramento

As part of the implementation team for the Epic - Health Connect (an electronic base record keeping system) as a Project Manager, I was given an opportunity to become a lead in various departments throughout Northern California.

Having the opportunity to work with healthcare professionals (medical staff, doctors, nurses, and management) improved my skill-set in several areas.

I learned the importance of delegating, facilitating an implementation process using strategic planning, and data management.

Each department had different requirements and expectations, and conducting training sessions for each of them required a creative, yet effective approach, while providing valuable information for all to understand.

This implementation was a learning experience for all levels involved; which created a few hiccups in the process, but it is expected with any pilot type advances on this scale.Innovation

Kaiser permanente is a great company to work for, the benefits are great and the company really take care of there employees. Kaiser offer a great retirement plan.The most enjoyable part of my job is the patients

great company I am glad I am able to work here. I wish it was easier to get a part time position I have been per diem for over a year.assiting nurses in patient care

I have enjoyed my years at Kaiser Permanente and I am only looking for another position so that I can go back to patient care. Kaiser Permanente is very generous with employees and extremely compassionate. Their heart is in the right place and the organization truly has taken "managed care" to a level that is well beyond the rest of the market. The people of Kaiser Permanente truly believe in capitation as the best method for not only reducing health care costs, but also for keeping people healthy. This is an organization with a mission and specific goals. They are all worthy goals.

Kaiser Permanente is also like a government bureaucracy. With over 175,000 employees, it is sometimes impossible to get things done in an efficient manner.Kaiser Permanente is a very compassionate and successful organization. Their heart is in the right place. But they are also a massive bureaucracy.

Working at Kaiser Permanente in Portland is so competitive it prevents team-work. Co-workers resent any offers of help and are less than friendly about helping out others when it is needed. Co-workers are great and fun to work with. They make an otherwise stressful job easier. Management and the union are work together which is good. However, there have been far too many instances where the union doesn't fight for us as it should. They are always in bed with management. Also, there is a lot of favoritism at the center I work at. Your best bet at advancement is if you hang out with management after work hours at bars, or if you flat out date them. I know a couple of people who applied to tons of jobs they qualify for but were never promoted. But once they started dating one of the male managers, less than 6 months, they got a promotion. If you are willing to compromise your personal integrity for the sake of advancement, you definitely will. This has been what I witnessed during my 5 years of working there. As an Union based employeer Kaiser rewards our hard work with top dollar wages, annual cost of living raises, as well as longevity paid (.30 for 10 years and increase every five years by .10), Bilingual pay, 5 weeks of paid vacation after 11 years of service. 15 days a year sick leave, 5 personal/life balance days, 6 paid holidays and double time and a half if you work the holiday, company paid medical benefits with low co-payment, full pension and a 401K plan with match 1.25 % of annual income as a one time payment based on how well the medical center did for the previous year. Profit share Program which is an annual bonus (amount Varies) basd on how the performance of staff at a medical center meets customer based services goals. * A typical day at work was primarily design, develop, test and deploy; then move on.
* What I learned was garnered mostly from co-workers. Off and onsite professional development was meager and of poor quality.
* Most managers were technically challenged and suspicious of the people they managed. Their decisions seemed mostly to be driven from up the chain and were arbitrary. They mostly managed projects first and people second. Therefore advancement and compensation raises were slow, with many years of no advancement nor increased compensation. In my 23 years at KPMG, I was fortunate to work under one individual who was an exception. He was highly intelligent, a great listener, relied on my judgement, was forward thinking and proactive in his planning and execution, and cared deeply for his people and their situations. I sincerely miss him.
* My co-workers were competent and hard working. Relationships reached beyond the workplace.
* The hardest part of the job was dealing with the partnership component of the structure. Partners were, in general, self-involved, uninspiring, arbitrary, and unfair. Benefits were expensive, 401K matching was nominal. We rarely saw any Partners. Partners (CPAs) referred to us as "non-professionals".
* The most enjoyable part of my job was being involved with my own projects as well as working in parallel with my peers whose expertise was commonly and easily shared. I benefited greatly from my close-knit peer group.KPMG EO was an acceptable workplace.
It was avery good time working in KPMG I could have experiece in managing clients, relationship, working wit people and being efficenceProactive in auditing and management roles

To be fair there are many benefits to working for a Big Four accounting firm. You will learn a ton of new information and you will grow as an employee. Employees get to work with many talented people. Not to mention a job at a Big Four looks great on your resume.

On the downside, if you look at the Best Places to work lists - you will find KPMG either listed below every other Big Four firm or completely absent from the list. Top management can make all the excuses they want but it comes down to two primary issues.

Management loves to take credit for success but blames underlings for failures. Either way you aren't going to share in the money pouring into the firm.

Second, management likes to play favorites and no one seems to be willing to reel these managers in. Companies need to be able to show why one employee was promoted over another and in many cases a halfway good lawyer could prove that this was not the case.

Over the years I watched countless talented employees jump ship to the other Big Four Accounting firms. As a result, many people who do remain and work up to Partner or Principal aren't the best and brightest.

If you find yourself working for this firm and want anything other than a very, very slow climb to the top - take as many classes as you can and constantly look for a position at one of the other Big Four Accounting firms. Many people I know jumped ship with their manager to a new firm and even entire departments have left together.

After working one too many 100+ hour work weeks for this firm I left and I would argue that any firm thatLeft for a better work/life balance & increase in salary.

A typical day at work involves identifying priorities based on milestones and clients needs and providing leadership to teams in managing and addressing them. Ongoing stakeholders analysis, reviewing deliverables, ensuring it meets required quality and scope, attending client meetings and project meeting. identifying selling opportunities and so on.

Management was always looking for ways to improve service and make more money. Co-workers made each day bearable and everyone had a passion for excellence.

The hardest part of the job was not being able to effectively balance job and family life when it mattered most and always having to sacrifice the latter.
