Redfin is an awesome company. I am currently employed as a full time agent. Before coming to Redfin, I was with a traditional brokerage. Redfin is NOT traditional. Redfin is different in its core values and beliefs, always making sure their customers are first. They are open, honest, transparent, and aren't afraid to tell you if they don't know the answer. Internal HR and IT departments are always super efficient and responsive to any concerns.

With all these differences, and because they put the customer first, your pay structure is going to not be what it would under a traditional brokerage. Don't let it fool you- paid mileage, bonuses, base salary, and benefits REALLY add up.

The environment here is great. Good, upbeat attitudes and honest people make working for Redfin the best thing I've ever done.Awesome Company Changing The Game
Awesome Company Changing The Game

Redfin is a company that only cares about their money. They will treat you like a slave. The pay is very low and the commission bonuses are a joke (Very Low). Managers act like they own the company and will band rules, and take advantage of the situation.

Managers will use your talent just ti make the company money and earn them self bonuses..

Do not make the same mistake that I made.Great company for part time extra money

Great part-time job and a lot of flexibility. The Dallas-Fort Worth team really is a good one, probably one of the better ones, and that goes a long way, based on what I see from reviews. I really don't have any complaints. Management? Great. Other agents we work with? Great. I truly believe the Redfin model is the way Real Estate should be. AA's (Associate Agents) don't work on commission. We get paid a flat fee for everything we do and I think we are paid fairly.Great company for part time extra money

Redfin is an incredible company to work for. Redfin offers employees a positive work environment with a bustling energy, encouraging workers to do their best. Employees do need to hold their own, look for their own resources at time and think outside of the box to get things done-employees have the power to make great change.

One big negative was the job uncertainty. During my time there an entire department was cut but, companies are always transitioning.Great company for part time extra money

I have been employed with Redfin for two years now as an Associate Agent. I work on my own schedule and make a great amount of extra money. Great Team. I work for another brokerage and received little to now training and with Redfin they are there with you to make you the best. I have learned more about showing houses, open houses, inspections, etc. movement throughout the company is possible as well.Great company for part time extra money
Great company for part time extra money

I am part of the Recruiting organization out of the Seattle HQ, and here's the truth:
1.) Things change fast, and you have to be adaptable and resilient. If you can roll with the punches, think at scale, keep the customer experience front and center, and roll-up your sleeves to execute strategy you'll experience career growth like nowhere else.
2.) If you get easily stressed out by ambiguity or change, this is not the company for you.
3.) Recruiting leadership has been hit/miss at times, but the new team gets it and this is the most excited I've been since joining Redfin.

The best parts of working at Redfin include the people, the ability to impact change and the benefits.

The hardest parts of working at Redfin include being at the whim of a turbulent real estate market and having to fight for resources sometimes makes it hard to get things done.Not a Real Estate Company

I worked at the Hub in Chicago for a demanding and unappreciative west coast market. I quit a higher paying job to take this with the hopes that I would like it more than what I was doing and I don't regret that decision. This was a great please to work! Pay is decent, but that is offset by the great benefits at a low cost to employees. Employees here feel valued and management is always willing to take suggestions on how to improve processes. Best job I have ever had!Not a Real Estate Company

Redfin is an incredible company to work for. Redfin offers employees a positive work environment with a bustling energy, encouraging workers to do their best. Employees do need to hold their own, look for their own resources at time and think outside of the box to get things done-employees have the power to make great change.

One big negative was the job uncertainty. During my time there an entire department was cut but, companies are always transitioning.Not a Real Estate Company

Redfin is a technological Company first and foremost and the only folks getting paid decent wages are the Seattle Engineers and Executives. Agents are paid based on reviews and sometimes regardless of how hard you work, you're not compensated regardless of the hard work you did. They claim paid benefits and dues, however your base salary is so menial along with bonus structure, you indeed are paying for all of those benefits they claim to offer. If you are a RE Agent and want unlimited earning potential, don't work at this place. If you're a brand new Agent with no experience, Redfin is a great place to start because they'll provide enough leads to keep you stressed out and under water. You will be expected to close a minimum of 3 deals per month, so forget any kind of work life balance. If you attempt to take a day off to decompress, you will be scolded and told you're not a team player. Also, given your compensation is tied to a review by the customer, you better be prepared to miss out on quiet time, family time, or even the birth of your children, because rest assure some consumer will claim in a review that you didn't respond to them in a timely manner and your already menial bonus will be cut further. The Average bonus after taxes is $1,000.00 and your base salary will be $10,000.00 so you do the math. A traditional Agent will be paid thousands in commissions, paid right away, and paid regardless of what the consumer thinks. Redfin's business model is rigged to keep you hungry enough to stay, but too poor to leave. Redfin also promotes unqualified individualsNot a Real Estate Company
Not a Real Estate Company

Redfin is an incredible company to work for. Redfin offers employees a positive work environment with a bustling energy, encouraging workers to do their best. Employees do need to hold their own, look for their own resources at time and think outside of the box to get things done-employees have the power to make great change.

One big negative was the job uncertainty. During my time there an entire department was cut but, companies are always transitioning.Associate Agent

I am a lead agent for Redfin and I love it! I wouldn't do real estate the "other" way ever again. The leads are fantastic and you have so many clients great clients.Horrible Place to Work - Don't Believe the Hype!
A week in the life as a Redfin AA is fun and involves a lot of driving and interaction with potential buyers through home tours, inspections, and more.False Advertising

Despite all the hype about Salesforce, there can be a large disparity of responsibility. Some teams had time to spend doing volunteer work during the work day and playing pool or ping pong in the lounge. I didn't have those luxuries. So a positive experience is dependent on the team. Also, if your management team is located in a different city, then you are at greater risk for a negative work experience.disparity of responsibility

Fast-paced environment, flexible schedule, great benefits like VTO (volunteer time off), WFH (work from home) and a fun and welcoming culture. There's a reason Salesforce continues to be voted a top employer time and time again.Fast-paced fun work environment
Great company, exceptional culture and great people around. Lot of fun and work life balance is top notch. Compensation part can be better but overall really nice company to workGreat Company

A typical day included a pretty steady flow of work. Minimum down time but enough time to be productive task wise. The workplace culture placed an emphasis on work/ life balance. Overall it is a great place to work.Great place to work prior to acquisition by another company
Great people, and benefits. Really poor management, and spending. Poor alignment of talent with work. You won't be heard unless you have been there 5 years or are a Sr. VP.Mixed bag

Some ppl make it, some ppl don't. Some territories catch fire, some stay cold. Some managers are much less militaristic, some are more. Doesn't matter what the issue may be there is someone underneath you working themselves to the bone for a shot at your spot. Targets are high and difficult to deliver on. Not for the faint-hearted.Cut throat, Stressful

This job could keep you up at nights depending on which department you are working in. Overall the company compensates you great but has found very stressful methods to keep employee on their toes.No Life
Great benefits/ salary, workplace culture and work environment. Supports career growth and cross company collaboration. Free snacks and many salesforce discounts.Overall good place to work
company with strong culture. rewarding and fun company to work for. lots of perks (games, parties, swag, stocks, time off, benefits, snacks, etc...) would recommendFun place to work with great people

My personal executive was an inspiration to me and others in the org. The hours were very long and work life balance not respected. High turnover, the global hours were grueling. Lack of advancement.Work life balance non existant

Compensation is above other companies, individual contributors are often responsible for all the work, but do not get the credit. Leadership and management needs to do better with communication.Work Hard, Play Harder

I would Image 6 Mac laptops within a day for new hires. Worked with other techs to make sure that all tickets have been updated within 24hours. I learned alot about the casper Imaging system for Macintosh computers and also Imaging Linux on HP Desktop computers.IT Provisioning technician

Daily work is not tough; Very strong scrum team(generally director level scrum master and product manager). Compensation is good and transparent for engineers. Cross team communication is not very easy.Good place to work

Payed a lot, but didn't learn terribly much and didn't get much performance feedback until right before I left.
Never got much work, which is good and bad (pretty normal for internships)Great pay, decent experience
SFDC was a wonderful company to work for. Great people, good pay and benefits, always a challenge. The company was also very philanthropic with lots of opportunities to give backGreat Place to Work

Great opportunity to learn something new everyday. The company offers great benefits and the access to self guided learning if you can find the time. The work is complex and you are encouraged to be creativeGreat Company with poor leadership

Salesforce is an awesome company to work for. Although I am contracted I fell in love with the Ohana family. The environment is fun but still everyone comes in ready to work and meet their goals. I would definitely want to grow with this company.Full of Energy and Fun workplace

Excellent Sr. management has propelled Salesforce into an industry leader. Company provides generous benefits; opportunities for advancement. Much expected of an individual. Good balance of work and home life.Great company to be associated with

Salesforce company culture, benefits, work/life balance and flexibility are pretty good. There are certain areas within Salesforce that are much better than others (R&D/product side of the house, HR, etc) seem to be run very well, care about their employees and have great career development in place. IT, has the same benefits, but lacks both the career growth/development opportunities, and positive management. I'd suggest if you are considering Salesforce and are technical go to R&D and steer clear of IT. Otherwise, loved the culture and environment.Good benefits, compensation, culture, specific areas have issues

Great place to work. However, in my role as Senior Solutions Manager, I needed to be on the road to client locations around 90% of the time.Outstanding place to work if your are an IT Consultant looking for Travel.

Every day is a tiring but rewarding day when I was with salesforce. The whole salesforce team collaborates well and interact with everybody. Which made the management a pat on its backi love being here

Salesforce is an amazing opportunity to learn about the world of information technology in the cloud. There is an incredible steep learning curve and bombardment of information however the longer you stay the more you start to grasp significance and advantages of each vertical. Salesforce is one of the best companies to experience and they have upward mobility for anyone willing to work for it.Productive and Fun Place to Work
Salesforce is a good place to work. Fun, smart and energetic co-workers. Long hours and they expect you to get results. Lots of sales enablement training.Good Place
great culture, good poeple to work with and nice work / life balance. pay is ok but great benefits. not much spendings on IT operations.good company

Wrok life balance is a plus and the location is amazing. My team was very involved and helped integrate me into the Salesforce community. Salary is very competitive and well worth it for the location and standard of living. Very open feel. Great company.Would Recommend
Good,fun people to work for. A very fun job culture to be around. good benefits,higher than normal pay,Fun awsome people to work around.productive place to work with a 75 inch screen in the office.

My time at Salesforce was much appreciated. I was working for Buddy Media (a startup) which was bought by Salesforce. Salesforce seemed to maintain some of the same culture of the startup along with solid benefits. Salesforce encouraged self starters to excel and those who needed help got help.Product, smart
Great company to work for although they are disorganized. I am two months into my new comp plan and have not even seen it yet!Salesforce-Great place to work

You make great money even as a part-timer. T-mobile pays you hourly (every 2 weeks) and a commission check each month.

It has an enjoyable culture.
Mangement is all hands on deck to assist with any questions or concerns.

Quotas are unrealistic to meet in slow months.fun and competitive workplace

Productive atmosphere with great benefits.
Learned about communications.
Learned how to manage other employees
Learned how to develop customer rapportProductive Atmosphere
TMobile was a good company to work for. The pay was good and the benefits were okay. Management could have been a little better. The location was great and we had lots of fun.T-Mobile
Relaxed place to work, great pay, paid time off. The hours arenâ€™t bad. The staff is friendly, there is no cut throat type of sales environment. Sales are fair, no undercutting.Relaxed environment
a typical day at work would start by going what are the goals for every individual and for the whole store also what can we do different to bring in more customersproductive workplace

Shifts cycle out every 6 months and then you bid for another shift with ranking system based on performance. Customers are tedious to deal with but management is micromanaged to a 't'. Team builders are encouraged and there are lots of perks from working there.Repetative
It was alright. i wasn't impressed with the fact that there wasn't much benefits given to the workers. you basically were a customer with a team shirt.okay job

I was challenged from day one. I began as a Receptionist, then moved into Human Resources as an HR Administrative Assistant and ended as an Administrative Assistant supporting everyone from the Director, Sr. Manager, Managers, Coaches and Customer Service Representatives.

It was a fast paced work environment with many deadlines to meet, prioritizing and time management was the key to my success.

I never dreamed I'd take on the responsibility of being the site graphic designer and photographer, I enjoyed this most of all and it was something I'd always wanted to do.

The workplace culture was like no other company I'd worked for, it was an environment of respect and acceptance.The work experience at T-Mobile was challenging and satisfying.

T-Mobile offered excellent benefits. The work environment was relaxed and non-stressful. The management staff was professional and helpful. The training was great and really prepared you to be successful at your job.Excellent Benefits

If you like selling and can gain the trust of customers, you'll love working for T-Mobile. The pay is amazing and there is no crab in the bucket mentality here. My most favorite job of all!Best place I have ever worked
T-Mobile is one of the best compaies to work. You make very good commission if you are good at selling and you have your hourly rate on the side. You also get all the benefits!T-Mobile is the best!

I very much enjoyed working at T-Mobile. I definitely could have seen myself there for a long long while, but since this was my first "real" company I worked for out of college, I wanted to gain additional experience outside of T-MobileA great 7.5 year run

Tmobile corporation has a good urban culture, and corporate structure. However, they rely heavily on Third party vendors to sell their service and these vendors do not share the same structure and this causes serious limitations with culture, and benefits. Tmobile should keep all stores corporate and eliminate the Third party modelTpri

Although there is a lot of opportunities when working for the T-Mobile call center; there is still room for growth when it comes to how things are managed and making sure that employees are erogonomically assessed when working on the floor. I initially enjoyed working for the company but the lack of communication between my supervisors and HR made things more difficult than they should have been and as a result, I suffered an injury to my left arm.Opportunities

Great place to work. Absolutely love it. They don't pay as much as Verizon or At&t but its a much happier place to be. The absolute worst part about this job is most definatley the miserable, hard to deal with, ungrateful, and brain dead customers. But the company is great to the employees and provides a great place to go to everyday. I give T-Mobile 5 stars for sure!Working for Tmo

The company offered very good benefits on competitive pay.

Team effort offered very good bonuses.

I worked at the metropcs branch which was a team commission every month.Very fun place to work

the work environment is very fast pace, competitive and always keeping you on your toes! You get to meet people every day and help guide them to their purchase. if you work with a great team, work is always fun. Hardest part of the job is that it can be stressful only if you don't meet quota at the end of the month. you basically make your own pay check. Great benefits! Management depends on the store, I've had 3 different managers who were all different. I learned a great deal on customer service.Great Place to work!

Fun place to work with lots of great benefits - almost 4 weeks vacation, lots of paid holidays, fun vendor events, perks and friday fun events.

Not a great place for IT career.Great place to work

The core values of Tableau were part of what drew me to this company. They seemed genuine and willing to put the time into cultivating great employees. Soon however it was very clear that these were just words on paper to many people in leadership roles. You were clocked and treated as hourly employees even if you were of a salary position. Never in my years at any other company was I treated as if I were not an adult that could manage my time and workload accordingly. Many times I was told by leadership that my opinion did not matter because I was not a manager, which was clearly indicated at review time when there were no peer reviews done or manager feedback (these were both leadership discretionary calls how convenient.). I truly cared about my team and the people I worked with but leadership (of atleast my org) had no business having direct reports and no amount of free food can change that.Core values rarely upheld by leadership

Great people, great product, snacks, drinks usually available. I have really enjoyed working here until the demands to meet metrics became the main focus of the job. They are not replacing people that have left quick enough so the workload is high.Great culture but lacks proper technical training

Tableau will the ideal place to work, if you do not care about the money. Stock option is pretty amazing as well, but salary increase and moving up to higher position would not be easy.A great place to work but doesn't pay much

I work in the scheduling department for Tesla Energy (on the solar side of things) and while the company is great, since they acquired SolarCity they took their management with it. Since the acquisiton the people that have been kept and promoted in management are doing a terrible job and the employee morale is way low, to the point where employees are trying to unionize, schedule days where everyone calls out, etc. The same people who have been here for years are making as much as four dollars an hour less than people just starting. As a company Tesla is great, they offer us good benefits at low cost and offer a lot of extra curricular learning activities and sponsor things like employee sports.Great Company With Poor Leadership

Many quit or were let go due to terrible management. If you stayed quiet and listened strictly to management rules then you were safe from repercussions. The workplace culture was not very good (i.e., certain types of harassment). Many of the customers were wonderful to interact with, though.Terrible Management

its a pleasure working along side the talents ive been around but management is horrible and makes you never want to be in the car business again. Theres a lot of work and you barely have time to live a life but the pay is worth it.Great company horrible leadership

Working @ TESLA has been nothing short of a great opportunity. Due to the nature of the company, being one of the largest and greatest in the sustainable energy field (which is actually the primary basis of the company with automobiles being a secondary component), its a great place to work if you like to be on the cutting edge. The company offers a lot to its employees, which is amazing, including paid time off, flexible hours and locations, and great management (depending upon timing and location) but it does have some things to learn. For example, management is there for when you need them, but sometimes its hard for them to get back to you when you directly need them. You have more than enough training, and people who are willing to help you with any of the company's products, but to get a decision from direct management can be difficult. But communication is good between branches, and employees, and the lifestyle is great to sell as it sells itself. For a car guy like me, working with the greatest automotive product since the Model T is simply the coolest idea, and beats any of the negatives about this job, which are few, but there are some. Overall, a wonderful experience, just not for people who want to move up fast and get paid that imaginary $1 Million salary immediately. There is possibility for growth, but it takes time.Wonderfully Limited

Too much was required of me when I was not clocked in. Hi-stress with quotas and deadlines. Base pay is better than fair (considering similar positions) - with commission bonus the sales/lead generation positions could pay well. If you are a go getter you can advance here but you will need to make good relationships with higher up's 1st.great cuse
The people who you work with, the benefits and the company's mission is fantastic, but the work/life balance is hard and your days can get really repetitive.Good Place to Work for 2-3 Years
Tesla has a very well developed working environment. I learned how to interact with my co workers when it came to working on long and short term projects.Great

The best part of the company is the people; everyone who is here truly believes in the mission, and it's an inspiring atmosphere to be in. They've managed to find a way to find the best people. However, as the company has grown, the priorities have changed, and the comp plans have changed with it; many people (myself included) are unhappy with their current pay for the amount of work put in. Hardest part is total lack of work-life balance.Phenomenal colleagues, nonsensical and frequent compensation plan changes, poor work-life balance

Since Tesla purchased Solarcity the quality of management has declined, worked has doubled and pay has shrunk. You do the work of 2-3 people daily and get paid less then one person should make.stressed out

Learn on the fly. One of the most innovative companies I have ever worked for. Benefits are amazing. Meeting stretched goals everyday is the norm.Everyone works as a team and pushes each other for their best.Fast Paced

Great place to work. If you are their for just the great earning and benefits then you will not make it far. The person must share the same vision as the company to last working at Tesla.fast pace and meticulous

Long hours, morning and night shifts. Two 5 star cafeterias with free beverages and snacks. Tesla offers great, low-costing benefits for workers and entire family.Fun, fast paced career if you are into building automotives.
Make alot of money but have no time to spend it. If you are a temp the likely of you getting fired for something petty is high. Not much job security.Hard work

I worked on the PV Design team, I was hired on right after Tesla accrued Solar City. Everyone there was nose to the grindstone, and the culture in our department was quiet and determined. Peoples salaries depended on how many jobs they could pump out each day, so most people always had their headphones in, took no breaks or lunch, and kept to themselves. I understand this is what some people like, but not me. I would have had to change my whole lifestyle to fit in there and work the hours they work.Stressful and no work-life balance

Tesla provide alot of free things over there. free sodas and cereals.
If you are planning to work make sure you are ready for 12 hours shifts. Tesla is a great place to work.Fun to work there

fast pace, productive and challenging working enviroment.I learned a lot. Good benefits. My most enjoyable part of the job is test drive vehicles.I love working here, but I am looking for higher paying job.fast pace and challenging

The compensation wasn't worth the work load. I found Tesla to be a stressful sales position. I have worked in sales for a long time, but this is the worse. Their sales tactics, that are mandatory, are pushy, rude and quite outdated, unless you like harassing customers shopping in Home Depot.The Stress isn't work 30K a year

They maintain work life balance. The management is fair in their decision and it is actually a good place to work. Only that the work done does not really commensurate with the pay received.Productive and relaxes

When I arrive, we have a passdown from the technicians from the previous shift. We then assess the equipment that is down and work according to priority and needs.Great place to work with great people

One of the best places you can dream to work.
Great people, great working conditions, nice benefits and working atmosphere. A lot of opportunities inside.One of the best places to work for

Texas Instruments (TI) offers good salaries and benefits. On the other hand, if you're into marketing, look elsewhere. TI doesn't hold marketing in high regard. The company's idea of marketing is a web page with a product datasheet.

There is little opportunity for growth and advancement in a marketing role. Positions that exist are typically awarded to white males under age 40 with a EE degree.

Sadly, there is a real disconnect between TI's corporate office and its field locations. Marketing personnel working outside of the Dallas headquarters are often passed over for jobs, no matter they might network. In the 16+ years I worked for TI, I saw a Human Resources representative in my office only two times. Both visits were made to conduct layoffs during a downsizing.Good Place to Kill a Marketing Career

In my last role I ended up working in a very stressful position with poor management, but in my other roles at Texas instruments I found the company fabulous. They really took care of me and provided amazing benefits. The company makes a big point to retain its employees for the remainder of their career.Long Term Company
good company to work. I have been with Ti for over 13+ years and really learned a lot. There are many growth opportunities and employee benefits. Nice culture to work.good company to work.

You either love the job and you'll work here forever or you hate it and you'll feel depressed the entire time you work here, employees are very cliquey like a high school you will literally be working and not talking to any one for 12 hours straighthit and miss
Work at texas instruments was kinda stressful and we had alot of machines to run and they were spread out. Alot of walking and standing. The workload was heticTexas

TI respected the work force and always accommodated to make production smoother and better. Events were held several times a year to celebrate accomplishments and they were always lenient on breaks.Loved working here

Great work environment and benefits but expect to work hard. Freedom to work around your life instead of live around your work. Opportunities for advancement and easy to feel good about your job.Research and Development Engineer

Challenging.
Learned a lot about all kinds of technology.
OK management.
Workplace culture was OK.
Worse part of being there was the low compensation.
Nice friendly people.Fun place to work.

If you're willing to give them your life, you'll make a good money. If life throws you a curve and that changes, it'll cost you. It was definitely a "what have you done for me lately" culture.Leadership varies across business

The company has great benefits time off allowances. The work was sometimes challenging but mostly routine. The only drawbacks were that although they push safety, don't ever bring a concern to your supervisor or you'll be labeled as a trouble instigator. The other is that you won't be disciplined for not carrying your weight or doing a quality job. The management doesn't want conflict.Great job, but too many deadbeats leaching the company

TI used to be a great place to work. Fast-paced, yet positive and enjoyable. However with the downturn of the market, constant lay-offs it turned into an ever increasingly cut-throat sweatshop. My job that was originally written as a technical position essentiall evolved into a communications position and when I balked, I was pushed out.

Strange that I can have a 12-year record of exemplary service and suddenly not able to do anything to expectations. Believe me, it wasn't me.

It is also very evident that they are replacing the older experienced people with younger people that can be paid a lot less.Changed
Mandatory 8 hour shifts, management staff like to "work from home", but zero flexibility for low totem pole members. Escalation process for inbound calls is rather cumbersome.Tsr role

The company provides outstanding benefits and takes care of employees. It is a large corporation which has its pluses and minuses. Overall I was very appreciative of my time with TI. They paid well and strove to continuously improve in all aspects of their products.Fast paced, ever changing

Love this job I would definitely recommend This Job to anyone a very relaxed. I'm good with pay and hours off weekends very friendly employees nice working area I just love everything about the jobLove this job

Great work environment with supportive management. Company wants employees to succeed and build a career. The best part about working at Twitter was the people and food.Great experience all around

Twitter was a good place to learn.
I liked my co-workers. One of the best teams I have had.
I did not like how much politics there were between directors and many manager. It was the worst place for this I have ever worked.Good place to work. I enjoyed my co-workers. Just the upper levels are too political.

Twitter is a great place for any company or local business to advertise upcoming events and exhibitions in a straightforward, simple manner. Making a post is fast and easy to plan in advance.Straightforward and Simple

Read this review 5 years from now. You'll understand the reason why it is now bankrupt and the company is defaulting failing. Horrible management unfair work conditions terrible work-life balance I wouldn't recommend this to anyoneTerrible company
i really liked working at Twitter. They have a cafeteria full of free food. they are conveniently located in Downtown SF where you can easily access the flagship location.Great company

A lot of great people here passionate about the platform and its role in the world. The challenge is how best to convey that to customers. The Google & Facebook duopoly is real. Twitter wants to consider themselves in that same realm, but our clients are more likely to categorize us in the "nice to have" bucket including Amazon, Pinterest and Snap.Fighting Hard to Maintain Relevance

it does seem to be getting better, albeit slowly but the people responsible for making day to day decisions don't always seem to make informed decisions. management seems to be more behind the curve and reactionary than able to plot out strategies and plan properly.great work life balance but poor leadership

Only nice thing was supportive coworkers and perks such as free lunches + perks.Not The Best Place To Be

UBER really is simply for the side hustle. It is not a reliable source of income and shouldn't be thought of as one. There were days i didn't make a single dollar, i simply didn't get any alerts, other days i was so busy i couldn't keep up. I found myself that the wages i was making were not enough to both compensate for gasoline and pay for the upkeep of my vehicle, which to work for UBER must be a newer model car. I don't think UBER is a great place to work, but it might be worth a shot for you.Uber is alright for a quick job

A great way to make a few extra bucks, but as you do use your own car, you will find the miles add up quick. Be prepared for some drunks, but also some interesting people. A vomit bag is a good investment.Uber is alright for a quick job

Really convenient for someone that needs a flexible work schedule. A lot of wear and tear on your vehicle. The app does work great nice and fluid user interface.Uber is alright for a quick job
Uber is alright for a quick job

I found working at Uber more disappointing than my initial low expectations. Guaranteed Earnings are one of the only ways to make real money and it usually doesn't work out. Management is not helpful and restaurants are often outright rude. Compared to other delivery companies Uber has nothing special to offer, the most basic one available and I do not recommend working there. While the delivery side of the job is easy enough to imagine if one is willing or not but the app used for Uber drivers crashes almost on every delivery, mixes the phone numbers of restaurants and customers, the power bank provided by the company charged my phone about 50% over a day and though the gear is sent through the mail and a 75 euro deposit is taken from you, I had to return it in another city when I finally decided to work somewhere else. Limited or no discounts are available to you compared to other places and many of my problems with the app for example were dismissed when contacting help. Last thing: Uber is the only delivery place which employs drivers in Winter and gives them a company t-shirt; any other company would provide a jacket or something that isn't a joke. Seriously, deliveries are great but work with another company.Not a career...

I likeed working at UBER. However, there has recently be an influx of drivers making it difficult to get riders. There as become so much competition where I sued to make $350.00 to $400.00 per day, I sometimes make less than $100.00 per day.Not a career...

As an independent driver it was good for making extra money but it wasn't good for a long term full-time job. There was a lot of wear and tear on my car and not much help with maintenance from the company.Not a career...

If you enjoy driving and talking to different people, then you'll like this job. It is mostly a part-time or supplemental type of job. If you want to make lots of money Uber driving then you'll need to work evenings and weekends. When you drive is entirely up to you. There is no schedule. It is the most flexible job you'll ever have. You don't need permission to take a break, or to take an afternoon off, or to take a day off, or to take a week off. You need to be self-motivated and self-disciplined in order for you to make money. You absolutely cannot be rude to your passengers. When I first started driving with Uber the compensation was great. As my employment continued, I received less and less of the percentage of the cost of the trip. The insurance company they use, James River Insurance, is a terrible company that still refuses to pay for damages I incurred while driving with Uber and are refusing to respond to my calls/emails. UberEat, the new segment of Uber is just as big of a scam. If anything goes wrong with the order, they will reimburse you a small percent of the cost of the delivery. This is a clear example how a poor organizational culture effects the employees/customers.Not worth it

The work were both enjoyable and stressful. The hours were flexible and controllable. The pay was average but decease for the hours worked. The customers were very grateful for an alternative way of getting transported to their desired designation.productive

The university's graduate students (ASE's- academic student employees) are unionized through the United Autoworkers Union, so we get decent benefits. Health insurance is covered including dental and vision. The salary was increasing slightly every year, although that was department dependent. One issue is that Seattle's cost of living is outpacing salary increase.Review of Graduate Student benefits

You may love working here if you are not an ambitious person. Many people rise in this company like they do all others, by brown-nosing, playing favorites and sabotaging coworkers. It's also dead boring. Some aspects are worth it if you can stand the above. The benefits are solid, except they did just cut one of the benefits down. It was essentially a pension, but now they only offer what amounts to a 401K. It's nice to have on a resume.Stepping stone

UWMC management is quite poor, generally, and completely out of touch with day-to-day operations. Compensation as regards take home pay is generally out-of-line with job duties. A typical work day was 2 full days of clinic and 3 half days. Working at UW you become part of a family, i have several relationships with people in my clinic an outside of my assigned clinic. We represent the "Patient First"motto,Fast paced Cardiology Clinic

Days at the University of Washington were rigidly controlled and stressfully paced, with an urge to complete more work than we had time/people to complete. Culture was very cutthroat. Pay was low, but benefits were excellent - however, free tuition for graduate programs was advertised, but never delivered because graduate programs had "fees" not "tuition."

Do not recommend.Quick-paced, cut-throat atmosphere

I really enjoyed my time at UW and I think it was a great place to work overall, with good pay, good benefits, and really interesting people to befriend. I had some trouble finding a good fit in terms of full-time/permanent positions and in terms of good management, but overall I think anyone would be lucky to work there.Good place to work

working at the UW is wonderful. great benefits, wonderful advancement opportunities. I would recommend working at the UW for anyone looking to gain valuable insights about their career.Working at the UW

UW is a great place to retire. They offer good benefits - medical, dental, vision, 403B, and pension. Reasonable work for the pay. Not a lot of room for advancement and do not give enough recognition for top performers. A stronger need for talent management and be willing to let under-performers go.A job you can retire in.

A typical day at work included scheduling appoints for patients, Triaging patient phone calls, checking in patients to the clinic and verifying their insurance. I learned how to use the scheduling program, how to use a multi-line phone. The management was troublesome as they were constantly in transition. Our lead was great at her job and was helpful and accessible. The doctors and medical staff were all fantastic but co-workers were a little bit of a challenge. The hardest part having to call really ill patients and let them know that there were no available appointments for months or when clinic was running behind schedule. The best part was the relationships I built with the medical staff.Fast paced clinic - great doctors

Working at UW can be exciting, depending on the job. In my experience, a typical day started at 8:00 a.m., and ended at 5:00 p.m. Break and lunch times were not as flexible, and start and end times were not, either.

I learned a great deal about the field of information, information systems, library systems, software development, data, data visualization, and using information for good. The best part of my job was being able to interact with the students we served, and seeing how the work I did positively and directly impacted them.

The hardest part of my job was the inflexibility of the schedule, and the pay. UW boasts excellent health benefits, but the pay is abysmal. After almost 8 years at UW, I could unfortunately no longer sustain myself on my former salary.

The management was mostly very positive, however, it was painful to see our director treat my supervisor in near-abusive ways. That type of toxic leadership trickled down to other staff members, and made it difficult to have a comfortable working environment.Not much change

Can't complain about health and vacation benefits, but I faced a situation where the management was very frustrating, especially from an IT perspective. I worked in a cost center which was very de-motivating, and there was a greater emphasis on meeting tight budget restrictions rather than actually doing quality work.Great health and vacation benefits, not great support for operational staff

If you find a good department, stay there and work there until retirement. It is that kind of place to work at. I recommend this place to people who hate working in industry or is just starting out.Great Place to Work at

Schedule Wise is flexible, very fun. Co-workers are great and traveling to different countries. Easy going co-workers, management is very flexible. great to end your retirement.Fun for retirement and easy job
Workday is awesome. Best workplace I have ever worked for, and I have been working since I was 16 years old (I am now 34). Super laid back work environment.Great Place to Work!

Culture is employee orientated and is a great place to work if you're in the right team with the right manager. Quality of management has been watered down since the enormous growth the last year or two.Good company Benefits and Culture
Workday really cares about their employees. They have great benefits and compensation packages. I would highly recommend this company to anyone who wanted to apply.Great place to work!

I've worked for other software giants, and no one compares to Workday! Their comp and onboarding for sales rep is like nothing I've ever seen. The benefits dept is also making huge strides in the family leave policy for 2017. Can't say enough great things about Workday!!AmaIng culture
Upper management is horrible. Co-workers and company culture are awesome. Amazing perks and benefits. Hardly any room for advancement in my department.Initially a great place to work.

Terrible management on the Enterprise Team. The culture in other organizations within the company are great and the teams are thriving. The Enterprise team, however, is unfortunately a different story. The leadership micromanages literally everything you do, the team morale is very negative, leadership doesn't take constructive criticism or suggestions and they are not invested in the training of their employees. It could be such a great team but the management and director are very junior and treat the job like an inside sales team but claim that it is not. The CEO and founders are absolutely incredible.Great company, poor management

Amazing company, co-workers, culture, management, and benefits. The role itself can get repetitive and a bit mind-numbing. But the right manager makes it worth while by boosting moral with team meetings, competitions, prizes, pot lucks, and so on. If not for my relocation, I would've wanted to stay long term.Associate Client Engagement Specialist

Zillow is a wonderful company, with the right management it is a pleasure to work there. Great benefits, wonderful training but I was unable to maintain my work life balance with the high pressure of the sales organization as well as my commute and moved on. Great people and culture.Wonderful company but very stressful sales environment

Great atmosphere and compensation. The difficulty, most of the better clients have already been claimed by other agents. Very challenging to find customers.Great company but very difficult to find good clients.

Zillow is a fantastic company as a whole. However, as a Client Engagement specialist, I feel overworked and under appreciated. We are expected to make a ridiculous amount of phone calls every day and were recently given schedules based on the amount of calls that we are doing every day, rather than the quality of work that we are doing. Since this has occurred, people have began cheating in their calls and not acting with integrity which is one of Zillow's core values. Client Engagement Specialist are also considered one of the most important departments in Zillow but we don't get to attend many of the work events and we have to work every day of the week, including holidays. Although, we volunteer for holidays, working a holiday to get a Saturday off is a hard toss up. I do not feel like I have any social life during my work week because I work 40 hours in 4 days and when I'm not at work, everyone else I know is because I have Wed-Fri off and spend my weekends at the office. For being there a year, I don't feel like I should be losing out on my social life just to follow through on Zillow's hours required to get agents connected to consumers.Great company if you're in the right department. Growing departments are having a hard time keeping up with the fun culture.

Every quarter, it seems they keep raising their standard of work ethics (absolutely no goofing around!) but highly rewarding with prizes and bonuses based on merit, which is fair. The high-volume work can seem a bit stressful at times, but you can always count on the support and guidance of your colleagues and team leads to help you every step of the way. It is also in their interest to see you succeed, so no excuses! ;)The best company ever!
Company doesn't care about individual employees. Terrible people in management positions. Exactly like high school. Great benefits. Free good. Will stab you in your back.Awful people

What an amazing company to work for. I just wish the rest of the company thought the same for me. The PAC department doesn't get the credit it deserves.

The job can be broken down in 3 sentences.

Easy training and connect customers to real estate agents. Make calls and document with simple online program.
Make 400 calls a day in a 10 hour shift.

That's it!

It's pretty simple and the pay ain't bad either. Starting is 17 an hour and quarterly bonuses and months bonuses for doing real well.

Amazing perks and benefits.
Really easy to get laid off.

When I was there. There was no QA and phone calls are still not recorded cause all you do is transfer calls. No help support of real info is traded. Just transfer and set up phone appointments. Over and over and over and over and over.Do you have a moment to speak to a real estate agent?
Benefits are amazing, but there is not a lot of room to grow. Management does not try and help your personal growth and development.Great benefits, poor advancement
Many employees unhappy and made for a non positive atmosphere. The benefits were by far the best of any company I have worked for.Great benefits, depressing atmosphere.

A Non-Sales Viewpoint:
ZIllow has a great culture and is full of amazing and intelligent people. If you want to work in a tech job with great work/life balance, amazing benefits, while surrounded by smart people, you should work at Zillow.

Hardest Part: The technical challenges. I think this should be the hardest part, because you aren't learning anything otherwise.

Most Enjoyable: Free lunches, co-workers, solving challenging problems.

ps- The CEO is awesome, everyone loves him!!Pretty Amazing Place
Excellent work environment & culture. Benefits are amazing with a fantastic management staff. Your income is based on your abilities to operate your own business.Excellent Work Enviroment
